page.title: 04Local History
page.content: Stauntion has a long and interesting {local history. }Bronze Age remains have been found at Mawly, and there is an anciant british camp at nearby Wapley Hall,attributed to { { Caracticus.}There is a Roman road running past the village from Shobden to Lyionshall. Stauntion is a {Saxion {settlement }, the name meaning 'strong place'. During the Dark Ages and later, feroius {border disputes }raged between the Welsh and English resulting at one stage in the making of Offa's Dyke lust over the Parish border. The Normans came and built a wooden Motte and Bailey cstle in Stauntion just behind the preasant church. In early medieval time there was another great wave of wood and stuble and clearence and sattlement and many local place names date from them.The last disturbance to leave
